about.profileImageAlt: A portrait photo of Rennan Lira
about.p1: Hello! I'm Rennan, a system developer and analyst with a deep-seated passion for technology. My journey began as a kid, captivated by the worlds inside a Super Nintendo. This fascination with video games grew through generations of consoles—from the PS1 to my current Xbox Series S—and evolved into a profound curiosity about how programs are built, how games are programmed, and the compelling stories they can tell.
about.p2: This passion first led me to earn a degree in Graphic Design from the SAGA START course at SAGA. Later, I pursued a degree in Analysis and System Development at UNIP. This blend of creative and technical skills landed me my first role at Almeida Advogados, where I had the opportunity to go above and beyond, from setting up server infrastructure to managing critical systems.
about.p3: Currently, I'm channeling my energy into developing a 3D isometric game with Godot and deepening my expertise in C, C++, and C#. I am a firm believer in constant learning and am always excited to dive into new technologies and frameworks. If it's tech, I'm in love with it.

items.title: Mastering React Hooks in 2024
items.excerpt: A deep dive into useState, useEffect, and custom hooks to streamline your component logic and build more efficient applications.
items.content:
## The Power of Composition

React Hooks have fundamentally changed how we write components. Instead of lifecycle methods in class components, we now compose logic using functions. This paradigm shift allows for incredible reusability and cleaner code. **`useState`** is the cornerstone, providing state to our functional components, while **`useEffect`** lets us handle side effects like data fetching or subscriptions.

* **useState**: For managing simple state like toggles, inputs, or counters. It returns a stateful value and a function to update it.
* **useEffect**: For synchronizing a component with an external system. It runs after every render by default, but you can control when it runs by providing a dependency array.
* **useContext**: To avoid prop drilling and pass data deep down the component tree.

## Building Your Own Hooks

The true power of Hooks is unlocked when you start creating your own. A custom hook is simply a JavaScript function whose name starts with "use" and that can call other Hooks. This allows you to extract component logic into reusable functions.

For example, you could create a `useApi` hook to handle data fetching, loading states, and error handling for any API endpoint. Or a `useLocalStorage` hook to persist state in the browser. This pattern keeps your components lean and focused on rendering, while the complex logic is neatly encapsulated and testable elsewhere. By mastering custom hooks, you're not just writing React, you're building a powerful, reusable library for your applications.

items.title: Why C# is a Game-Changer for Indies
items.excerpt: Exploring how C# empowers solo and small team developers to build complex and performant games in engines like Godot and Unity.
items.content:
## Speed, Safety, and a Powerful Ecosystem

For independent game developers, choosing the right language is a critical decision. While languages like C++ offer maximum performance, they often come with a steep learning curve and manual memory management. This is where C# shines. It provides a sweet spot between performance and productivity. **Its strong typing and garbage collection** significantly reduce common bugs and allow developers to focus on game logic rather than low-level memory details.

The ecosystem around C# is another massive advantage. With game engines like **Unity** and **Godot** offering first-class C# support, developers have access to vast libraries, a rich asset store, and a massive community for support and collaboration. This means you don't have to reinvent the wheel for physics, rendering, or audio.

## Beyond the Engine

The versatility of C# extends beyond the game client. You can use the same language to build your backend services with ASP.NET, create tools for your development pipeline, or even develop cross-platform applications with MAUI. This consistency streamlines the development process for small teams.

* **Rapid Prototyping**: Quickly test ideas and build prototypes without getting bogged down in complex boilerplate.
* **Scalability**: C# is robust enough to scale from a simple puzzle game to a complex, multiplayer RPG.
* **Hiring**: It's a popular and widely-taught language, making it easier to find talent and collaborate with other developers.

In essence, C# empowers indie developers to punch above their weight, enabling them to create polished, complex, and performant games without the overhead of more complex languages.

items.title: The Art of User-Centric Design
items.excerpt: Principles and practices for creating intuitive and delightful user experiences that keep users coming back for more.
items.content:
## Empathy is Your Superpower

At its core, user-centric design is about empathy. It's about stepping out of your own shoes and into the user's. Before writing a single line of code, we must ask: **Who is our user? What are their goals? What are their pain points?** The answers to these questions should guide every design and development decision.

Great user experiences aren't accidental. They are the result of a deliberate process that includes user research, creating personas, and mapping out user journeys. This groundwork ensures that we are solving real problems for real people, not just building features that we think are cool.

## Principles of Intuitive Design

An interface should feel intuitive, almost invisible. Users shouldn't have to think about how to use it; it should just work. Several key principles help achieve this:

* **Consistency**: Use consistent patterns, terminology, and layouts throughout your application. This makes the interface predictable and easy to learn.
* **Feedback**: The system should always provide immediate and clear feedback for every user action. Whether it's a button click or a form submission, the user needs to know what's happening.
* **Hierarchy**: Visually guide the user's attention to the most important elements on the page. Use size, color, and spacing to create a clear visual hierarchy.
* **Simplicity**: As Antoine de Saint-Exupéry said, "Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away." Strive for simplicity and clarity, removing anything that isn't essential.

By embracing these principles, we can move beyond building functional applications and start creating truly delightful experiences that users will love.

featuredProjects.title: Odyssey: Real-time Ray Tracing Engine
featuredProjects.description: A high-performance, from-scratch ray tracing engine built in C++ and Vulkan. It simulates realistic light physics, supporting soft shadows, reflections, and global illumination, optimized for modern GPU architectures.
featuredProjects.detailedDescription: Odyssey is a personal research project diving deep into the world of computer graphics. The engine is built from the ground up, providing complete control over the rendering pipeline. It uses the Vulkan API for low-overhead GPU communication, enabling high performance. The core of the engine is a path tracing algorithm that recursively traces light rays to produce photorealistic images.
featuredProjects.challenges: The main challenge was mastering the complexities of the Vulkan API and the mathematical concepts behind ray tracing. Implementing features like a Bounding Volume Hierarchy (BVH) for efficient ray-object intersection tests and developing shaders in GLSL for materials and lighting calculations were significant hurdles that required extensive research and debugging.
featuredProjects.outcome: This project has been an incredible learning experience, solidifying my understanding of low-level graphics programming, GPU architecture, and advanced C++. While it's an ongoing endeavor, the engine can already render complex scenes with realistic lighting, serving as a powerful testament to my systems programming capabilities.

featuredProjects.title: Project Chimera: Voxel Game Engine
featuredProjects.description: A custom game engine focused on procedural generation of infinite voxel worlds. Combines high-performance C++ for the core with a C# scripting layer for game logic, featuring dynamic mesh generation and a custom physics engine.
featuredProjects.detailedDescription: Project Chimera is a bespoke game engine designed specifically for creating vast, procedurally generated voxel-based worlds, similar to Minecraft but with a focus on custom rendering techniques. The engine's core is written in C++ for maximum performance in chunk management and mesh generation. A C# scripting API is exposed to allow for easy implementation of game logic, items, and character behaviors.
featuredProjects.challenges: Optimizing the 'greedy meshing' algorithm to reduce the number of vertices for rendering large chunks of voxels was a major challenge. Another was designing a flexible Entity Component System (ECS) architecture that could efficiently manage thousands of in-game entities. Interfacing C++ with C# required careful memory management and a well-defined communication layer.
featuredProjects.outcome: The result is a highly performant engine capable of rendering massive, dynamic worlds in real-time. The live prototype demonstrates smooth world exploration and interaction. This project showcases my ability to architect complex, multi-language systems and solve challenging problems in game engine development.

featuredProjects.title: Aether: Decentralized Storage Network
featuredProjects.description: An ambitious exploration into building a peer-to-peer, encrypted storage network using Rust. Focuses on data integrity, fault tolerance, and cryptographic security, aiming for a truly decentralized alternative to cloud storage.
featuredProjects.detailedDescription: Aether is a proof-of-concept for a decentralized storage network where users contribute their unused disk space to form a resilient, peer-to-peer cloud. Files are encrypted, split into chunks, and distributed across the network. Built in Rust, it leverages the language's safety and performance features to create a secure and reliable system.
featuredProjects.challenges: Implementing a reliable peer discovery mechanism using a Distributed Hash Table (DHT) was a complex networking challenge. Ensuring data integrity and redundancy through erasure coding and cryptographic proofs of storage was also a key focus. Managing asynchronous operations in Rust using async/await for handling many concurrent network connections was critical for performance.
featuredProjects.outcome: The project is currently in the development phase but has successfully implemented the core functionalities of file chunking, encryption, and peer-to-peer data transfer. It serves as a deep dive into distributed systems, advanced networking, and applied cryptography, demonstrating a strong grasp of modern systems programming with Rust.

items.title: Project Nebula
items.description: An interactive data visualization tool for astronomical data, built with D3.js and React.
items.detailedDescription: Project Nebula is a web application that provides an interactive, explorable visualization of the Hipparcos star catalog. Users can pan, zoom, and filter a 2D map of the galaxy, clicking on individual stars to get detailed information from various astronomical databases.
items.challenges: The primary technical challenge was rendering over 100,000 data points smoothly in a web browser. I solved this by using HTML5 Canvas for rendering instead of SVG, which significantly improved performance. I also implemented an intelligent data-caching and lazy-loading strategy to manage the large dataset efficiently. Performance-critical calculations could be offloaded to a C++ backend.
items.outcome: The project was featured on a popular data science blog and is used by amateur astronomers as a learning tool. It successfully demonstrates how complex datasets can be made accessible and engaging through thoughtful UX and performant frontend architecture.

items.title: E-Commerce Platform
items.description: A full-featured online store with Stripe integration and a custom admin dashboard.
items.detailedDescription: This is a full-stack e-commerce platform built from the ground up, designed to be robust, scalable, and easy to manage. It features a complete shopping experience, from product browsing and filtering to a secure checkout process powered by the Stripe API. It also includes a custom-built admin dashboard for managing products, orders, and customers.
items.challenges: Integrating the Stripe API for secure payment processing was a key challenge, requiring careful handling of sensitive data and webhook implementation for order confirmation. On the backend, designing a scalable database schema in PostgreSQL to handle product variants, user accounts, and order history was a complex but rewarding task. The backend logic was built with C# and ASP.NET for robustness.
items.outcome: The platform serves as a powerful demonstration of full-stack development capabilities. It's a production-ready template that can be customized for various e-commerce needs, showcasing expertise in both frontend (React) and backend (C#, PostgreSQL) technologies.

items.title: Task Management App
items.description: A sleek and intuitive to-do list application with real-time collaboration features.
items.detailedDescription: A modern task management application designed for team collaboration. It allows users to create projects, assign tasks, set deadlines, and communicate with team members in real-time. The UI is clean, intuitive, and highly responsive, built with React and Tailwind CSS.
items.challenges: The main challenge was implementing real-time data synchronization across multiple clients. I leveraged Firebase's Firestore database and its real-time listeners to ensure that any change made by one user (like adding a task or posting a comment) is instantly reflected for all other team members, creating a seamless collaborative experience.
items.outcome: The application is a testament to building modern, real-time web apps. It's used internally by a small design agency to manage their project workflows, and has significantly improved their team's productivity and organization.
